p.seg: Shan Bao forgot the external by focusing on the internal,
Zhang Yi lost the mean by pursuing the external.
Qi failed in taking Ji Xi due to its caution,
Qin impoverished itself by preparing for the Rong and Di barbarians.
These are all calamities arising from not combining.
Accumulating goodness and acting with trustworthiness,
are things often heard of;
being cautious in speech
and temperate in diet
are things scholars recognize.
Beyond this,
few or none know.
I will use my prior knowledge
to speak to those who will awaken in the future.
Scroll 5
On the Absence of Sorrow or Joy in Sounds
A guest from Qin asked the host of Dongye, saying:
"I have heard in previous discussions:
'The music of a well-governed world is peaceful and joyful;
the music of a fallen nation is sorrowful and reflective.'
Governance and chaos reside in the government,
and sounds and music respond to it.
Therefore, the emotions of sorrow and reflection
are expressed in metal and stone (instruments),
and the appearances of peace and joy
are manifested in wind and string instruments.
Furthermore, Confucius, upon hearing the Shao music,
Knowing the virtue of Yu Shun;
Ji Zha listened to the strings,
and knew the customs of the various states.
These are already established facts,
not doubted by former sages.
Now, you alone believe that sound has no sorrow or joy,
what is the reason for this?
If you have good news,
I now ask to hear your explanation."
The host responded, saying:
"This meaning has long been stagnant,
and no one is willing to rescue it.
Therefore, it has been passed down through generations,
and is indiscriminately applied in name and reality.
Now, receiving your enlightenment,
I will speak of one corner of it.
Heaven and earth combine virtue,
and all things value life.
Cold and heat alternate,
and the five elements are thereby completed.
Therefore, they are manifested as the five colors,
and emitted as the five tones.
The creation of sounds,
is like smells existing between heaven and earth.
Whether they are good or bad,
even if they encounter turbidity and chaos,
their essence remains as it is,
and does not change.
How could one alter their principles based on love and hate,
or change their measure based on sorrow and joy?
When the musical modes come together in harmony,
and the sounds are brought into concord,
this is the ultimate desire of the human heart,
the focus of emotions and desires.
The ancients knew that emotions could not be indulged,
and desires could not be pushed to extremes.
Therefore, according to their functions,
they always set limits,
so that sorrow would not lead to injury,
and joy would not lead to licentiousness.
They named things according to their functions,
and objects had their designations.
Crying is called sorrow,
singing is called joy.
This is the general outline.
However, when we speak of joy, joy,
is it just about bells and drums?
When we speak of sorrow, sorrow,
is it just about weeping and wailing?
Reasoning from this,
jade and silk are not the substance of respectful reverence,
songs and dances are not the essence of grief and sorrow.
How can we make this clear?
Because in different regions and customs,
singing and crying are different;
if they were used interchangeably,
some might hear crying and rejoice,
or listen to singing and feel sorrow.
Yet the emotions of joy and sorrow are the same.
Now, using the same emotions,
we produce myriad different sounds;
is this not proof that sounds have no fixed nature?
Yet sound and tone, when harmonious and comparable,
are the most profound in moving people.
Those who labor sing of their toil,
those who rejoice dance to commemorate their achievements.
When there is sorrow in the heart,
then urgent and mournful words are expressed.
When words are compared, they become poetry;
when sounds are compared, they become music.
Mixed together, they are chanted;
gathered together, they are listened to.
The heart is moved by the harmonious sound,
the emotions are touched by the sorrowful words.
Sighs and laments have not ceased,
and weeping and tears flow ceaselessly.
For the sorrowful heart is hidden within,
but is released after encountering harmonious sound.
Harmonious sound has no form,
but the sorrowful heart has a master.
To take a sorrowful heart that has a master,
and to base it upon formless harmonious sound,
the only realization that results
is sorrow itself.
How could one further understand that the sounds of myriad things are different,
and allow them to be as they are themselves?
The flow of customs
then forms their governance.
Therefore, national histories clarify the gains and losses of governance and education,
examine the flourishing and decline of national customs,
and recite emotional feelings
in order to remonstrate with those above.
Therefore, it is said:
the music of a fallen state is mournful and longing.
Now, joy, anger, sorrow, happiness,
love, hate, shame, and fear,
all these eight,
are how the people interact with things and transmit emotions,
distinguishing categories to which they belong,
and should not be excessive.
Now, flavors are defined by sweetness and bitterness.
Today, because A is wise, we feel love in our hearts,
and because B is foolish, we feel hate in our emotions.
Then love and hate should belong to me,
while wisdom and foolishness should belong to them.
Can we call it "loving people" because I love them,
or call it "hating people" because I hate them?
Should we call it "liking flavors" because we like them,
or call it "hating flavors" because we hate them?
Speaking from this perspective,
then outside and inside have distinct uses,
and "they" and "I" have different names.
The value of sound should primarily be judged by its quality of being good or bad,
which has no necessary connection to emotions like sorrow or joy.
Sorrow and joy should arise from genuine feelings,
and should not be intrinsically dependent on sound itself.
If we remove both the name (sound) and the reality (emotion) as intrinsically linked,
then the matter can be seen clearly.
Furthermore, when Ji Zi was in Lu,
he collected poems and observed rituals,
in order to distinguish proper and depraved airs.
Did he merely rely on the sounds alone to determine good and bad?
Moreover, when Zhong Ni (Confucius) heard the Shao music,
he praised its perfect harmony,
and therefore sighed in admiration.
Was it necessary for him to understand the virtue of Yu Shun through the sound,
before he could praise its beauty?
If I crudely explain one aspect of this,
it should be enough to understand more than half the issue."
The Qin guest objected, saying:
"In the eight directions, customs are different,
and songs and cries vary greatly.
However, the emotions of sorrow and joy
cannot help but be revealed.
For the heart is moved within,
and the sound issues forth from the heart.
Even if it's expressed through other sounds,
or conveyed through subtle tones,
a skilled listener
It is necessary to be aware of oneself so as not to err.
In the past, when Bo Ya played the zither,
Zhong Ziqi knew his aspirations;
when a servant struck the chime stone,
Zichan recognized the sorrow in his heart;
when a man from Lu cried in the morning,
Yan Yuan discerned that it was due to a living separation.
Now, these several individuals,
how could they have relied on common sounds for intelligence,
or borrowed verification from the tune's measure?
When the heart is grieved, the form moves accordingly;
when the emotion is sorrowful, the sound becomes mournful.
This is a natural correspondence,
which cannot be escaped.
Only those with divine insight can truly grasp this.
A skilled person does not find difficulty in many sounds,
while an unskilled person does not find ease in few sounds.
Now, one should not say that sound has no discernible principles
simply because one has not encountered a good listener;
nor should one say that sounds have no sorrow or joy
simply because one sees the many changes in local customs.
It is also said:
The wise should not readily speak of love,
and the foolish should not readily speak of hate.
However, it is after one is wise that love arises,
and it is after one is foolish that hate is formed.
It is merely that they should not share the same name.
The arising of sorrow and joy
There is also a reason for it.
This is because the *sound* makes me grieve,
the *music* makes me happy.
If grief and happiness are caused by sound,
and are even more substantial than that,
how can both name and reality (reputation and substance) be dismissed?
Furthermore, it is said:
Ji Zi collected poems and observed rites,
in order to distinguish the *Feng* and *Ya* sections of the *Book of Songs*;
Confucius sighed at the perfect harmony of the *Shao* music,
and thus praised it.
What are you saying?
Moreover, when Master Xiang played a *cao*,
Confucius saw the image of King Wen;
when Master Juan presented a melody,
Zi Ye recognized the music of a fallen state.
Would they have to study the *Book of Songs* before commenting,
or practice the rites before establishing a critique?
These were all uniquely insightful and divinely perceptive,
not requiring prolonged listening for days,
before grasping their auspiciousness or ominousness;
therefore, former historians considered them beautiful anecdotes.
Now, you, with your limited knowledge,
confine yourself to what you see,
are you not slandering the subtle discernment of previous worthies,
and betraying the profound insight of Confucius?"
The host replied,
The *Nan*
says: "Though songs and cries are vastly different,
those skilled in listening and discerning must be aware of it themselves.
They do not rely on intellect for common sounds,
nor do they borrow verification from melodic structures.
That is what people like Zhong Ziqi are talking about."
This means that those whose hearts are filled with sorrow,
even if they engage in conversation and encouragement,
and those whose emotions are filled with joy,
even if they beat their chests and sigh,
still cannot conceal themselves by controlling their outward appearance,
deceiving the observer with uncertainty.
It is thought that even if sounds are impermanent,
there should still be indicators of sorrow and joy.
It also says:
"Ji Zi listened to music [lit. sounds] and
knew the customs of various states;
Master Xiang played the *cao* [a type of musical composition] and
Zhong Ni (Confucius) saw the appearance of King Wen."
According to what is said,
this means that King Wen's merits and virtues
and the flourishing or decline of customs
can all be represented in sounds.
The lightness or heaviness of sounds
can be passed on to later generations,
and the skills of Xiang and Juan [musicians]
can be acquired in the future.
If that is the case,
The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors
cannot be said to have ceased to exist today,
so why only count a few things?
If this were really the case,
then King Wen's playing would have a fixed standard,
and the music of Shao and Wu would have a set number of notes,
and could not be mixed with other variations,
nor played with extra sounds.
If that were the case, the so-called inconstancy of sounds
and Master Zhongzi's ability to understand by analogy
would stumble here.
But if the inconstancy of sounds
and Master Zhongzi's ability to understand by analogy
are indeed true,
then Confucius's ability to recognize subtle nuances
and Ji Zha's skill in listening
would also be false;
these are all reckless records by common Confucians,
wanting to mystify the matter and creating these stories afterwards.
They want the world to be confused about the way of sounds,
without speaking of inherent principles.
If we extend this logic
it makes it appear that the divine and wonderful are difficult to know,
regretting not encountering a remarkable listener in their own time,
admiring the ancients and sighing to themselves.
This is why they greatly mislead later generations.
When reasoning by analogy and distinguishing things,
one should first seek the principles of nature.
The principle is already established,
and then we borrow ancient meanings to clarify it.
Now, if we have not attained it in our hearts,
but rely heavily on previous words as evidence for discussion,
from this point forward,
I fear even the most skilled calendar-makers will not be able to record it all.
Furthermore, it is difficult to say:
that the creation of sorrow and joy
is like love and hate arising from virtue and foolishness.
This is to say that sounds cause me to be sorrowful,
and tones cause me to be joyful.
If sorrow and joy originate from sounds,
then they become even more substantial.
Now, the five colors have beauty and ugliness,
and the five sounds have goodness and evil.
This is the nature of things.
As for love and not loving,
liking and not liking,
these are changes in human emotions,
and the principle governing all things
stops only at this point.
However, all these have no prior connection within,
but are formed in response to external things.
As for sorrow and joy arising from events,
first encountered in the heart,
but then relying on harmonious sounds
to manifest themselves,
therefore, the previous discussion already made clear their impermanence.
Now, I again borrow this discussion to rectify names and terms.
It is not to say that sorrow and joy originate from sounds,
just as love and hate arise from the wise and foolish.
However, the way harmonious sounds move people's hearts
is also like how wine brings out people's nature.
Wine primarily focuses on sweetness and bitterness,
but those who are drunk use joy and anger.
To see joy and sorrow manifested in sound,
and then say that sound possesses sorrow and joy,
is like saying that joy and anger are caused by wine,
and then claiming that wine possesses the principles of joy and anger."
The Qin guest challenged, saying:
"To observe qi and discern colors
is a common practice throughout the world.
When the heart changes internally,
the complexion responds externally;
this is clearly visible,
hence you, sir, do not doubt it.
Now, sounds
are the result of qi being stirred.
The heart responds and is moved by emotions,
and sound changes and is produced accordingly.
The heart has waxing and waning,
and sound also has rise and fall.
Both are subject to the same body;
why is it only with regard to sound that you should have doubts?
Joy and anger are manifested in facial expressions,
Sorrow and joy should also be expressed in sounds.
Sounds naturally possess sorrow and joy,
but the ignorant cannot recognize them.
As for those like Zhong Ziqi,
even when encountering irregular sounds,
they can perceive them clearly and uniquely.
Now, blind men face a wall and remain unaware,
while Li Lou sees an autumn hair at a hundred xun (a unit of length).
Speaking in this way,
brightness and darkness have different abilities.
One cannot adhere to a foot's length measurement
and doubt Li Lou's keen observation;
clinging to the hearing of the Doctrine of the Mean
and suspecting Zhong Ziqi's acuity.
All say that the ancients recorded falsely."
The host replied:
"You argue:
The heart responds to feelings and moves,
sound arises from changes and is emitted.
The heart has its flourishing and declining periods,
sound also has its rising and falling.
The emotions of sorrow and joy
must be expressed in sounds.
Those like Zhong Ziqi,
even when encountering irregular sounds,
can perceive them clearly and uniquely.
If it were truly as you say,
Then the fullness of turbid substance,
the starvation of Shouyang,
the injustice of Bian He,
the sorrow of Boqi,
Sima Xiangru's containing anger,
the fear of divination being inaccurate,
all manifest in a thousand transformations and a hundred states.
If each were to utter a song of lament,
and together initiate a few subtle notes of music,
then those like Zhong Ziqi,
would each discern the emotion therein.
As one who listens to sounds,
do you not change your thoughts because of fewness or multitude?
As one who examines emotions,
do you not differentiate based on size or smallness?
Those that originate from the same body,
aim to understand them.
If one were to produce (sound) from below (common people),
then those like Shi Kuang,
should also take up the pitch pipes and play the pipes,
to examine their tones,
knowing the waxing and waning of the Southern Wind,
and distinguishing the licentiousness and correctness of the Ya and Zheng airs.
As for eating spicy food and laughing heartily,
and the smoke stinging the eyes and sorrowful weeping,
both use the excretion of tears.
If you made Di Ya taste them,
he would surely not say that joyful tears are sweet,
and sorrowful tears are bitter,
this can be known.
Why is this?
Flesh fluids and sweat,
when pressed, easily come out,
without being governed by sorrow or joy.
It is like the straining of a wine bag;
although the straining tools are different,
the taste of the wine does not change.
Sounds all come from the same body,
why must they necessarily contain the principle of sorrow and joy?
Moreover, the *Xianchi* and *Liujing*,
the *Dazhang*, *Shao*, and *Xia*,
these are the supreme music of the former kings,
by which they moved Heaven and Earth and influenced ghosts and spirits.
Now, if it must be said that sounds invariably resemble their substance and transmit their hearts,
then this must be supreme music,
and cannot be entrusted to blind musicians and historians.
It must be that the sage regulates its strings and pipes,
only then can refined music be fully realized.
Shun ordered Kui to strike the stone and pat the stone,
and the eight tones were harmonized,
and gods and men were at peace.
Speaking of this,
although supreme music awaits a sage to create it,
it is not necessary for the sage to perform it himself.
Why is this?
Sounds have a natural harmony,
and is not connected to human sentiment.
The sound of harmonious accord
is produced by metal and stone (instruments);
the sound of ultimate harmony
is obtained from wind and string instruments.
Even the slightest detail has a discernible form,
thus it is that those who can see are distinguished from the blind by their different abilities to perceive light and darkness.
If one mixes water with water,
how is that different from anything?"
The Qin guest countered, saying:
"Although many analogies have hidden flaws
sufficient to invite attack and criticism,
nevertheless, the grand principle
surely has some merit.
For example, Ge Lu heard the bellow of an ox
and knew that his three sons would be sacrificed;
Shi Kuang blew his pitch pipe
and knew that the Southern Wind would not continue,
and the Chu army would certainly be defeated;
the mother of Yangshe listened to her son's cries
and knew that her family would soon be ruined.
All of these events
were modeled on the ancient world,
therefore they were all recorded.
Reasoning from this,
then flourishing and decline, good fortune and bad,
all exist in sound.
Now, if we were to again call it deception,
then previous words and past records
would all become discarded objects,
of no use whatsoever.
To speak in general terms,
I cannot feel at ease with this.
If you can clarify the reason for this,
reveal its cause,
and establish that both arguments are valid,
I would gladly hear it again."
The host replied,
"I believe that one who can infer from three corners,
obtains the meaning and forgets the words.
Therefore, the previous discussion was brief and not detailed.
Now, you trouble me again with this difficult circular argument,
how dare I not exert myself wholeheartedly?
The Lu ox was able to recognize the tragic death of the sacrificial calendar,
and lamented the passing of the three sons,
harboring sorrow for years,
and complaining to Ge Lu.
This shows that its heart is the same as a human's,
differing only in its animal form;
this is again what I doubt.
Moreover, oxen are not humans,
and have no shared ways of understanding.
If you say that birds and beasts all possess,
◇Ge Lu's imparted nature,
To understand it alone;
this is called "addressing the language to discuss the matter,"
it's like translating foreign languages.
If one does not examine the sounds to understand the feelings,
then this is not what is considered difficult.
If it is said that a wise person
should understand upon encountering things,
knowing everything,
let us first discuss what is easy.
I ask, if a sage suddenly entered barbarian territory,
would he know what they are saying or not?
The challenger will surely say:
He would know it.
What principle explains this "knowing it"?
How can it be clarified?
I wish to use your challenge to establish the domain of discernment.
Would it be by interacting with the gatekeepers to understand their language?
Or by blowing pitch pipes and playing pipes,
to compare their sounds?
Or by observing their demeanor and analyzing their expressions,
to know their hearts?
This "knowing the heart"
comes freely from demeanor and expressions;
even if they do not speak,
one will still know it.
The way to know it
does not necessarily require language.
If one blows pitch pipes and compares sounds
to know their mind.
Suppose one's mind is set on a horse,
but they mistakenly say "deer,"
the observer should certainly use "deer" to understand "horse."
This is because the mind is not bound to the spoken word;
words may not be sufficient to prove the mind.
If one understands speech only by relating it to specific situations,
this is like a child learning language from their teacher,
and only then understanding it.
Then what value is there in intelligence?
Speech is not something naturally fixed;
in the five regions, different customs
use different names for the same thing.
One simply chooses a name
to serve as a label.
Sages exhaustively investigate principles,
saying that nature can be explored,
and nothing is too subtle to illuminate.
If principles are obscured, then even what is near will not be seen;
therefore, the language of a foreign land
cannot be forcibly understood.
Extending this reasoning,
how can we say that Ge Lu did not completely fail to understand the bellowing of an ox?
Isn't that possible?
Furthermore, I have a difficulty, saying:
Shi Kuang, by blowing his pipes,
knew that the southern wind was not strong,
and that there would be many deaths in Chu.
This is also what I doubt.
May I ask, when Shi Kuang blew the pitch-pipes,
was it the wind of the Chu Kingdom?
If so, separated by a thousand *li*,
the sound would not be sufficient to reach.
If he truly recognized the wind of Chu
and inserted it into the pitch-pipes,
then Chu has Wu and Yue to the south,
and Liang and Song to the north.
If one does not see its origin,
how can one recognize it?
Generally, when *yin* and *yang* are stirred up
then wind is formed.
The *qi* interacts,
touches the ground and is released.
How can it be released from the court of Chu
and enter Jin?
Moreover, the pitch-pipes merely divide the *qi* of the four seasons.
When the time arrives, the *qi* moves;
when the pitch-pipe responds, the ash moves.
All naturally await each other,
not requiring human agency to be used.
The upper generating the lower,
is how the harmony of the five tones is equalized,
and the division of firmness and gentleness is ordered.
However, the pitch-pipes have a fixed sound.
Even if one blows the *zhonglü* pitch-pipe in winter,
its sound is naturally full and without loss.
Now, with the spirit of the people of Jin,
blowing a tune without rhyme,
how could the wind of Chu possibly enter into it
and cause it to wax and wane?
Wind has no form,
and sound is incompatible with musical pitch.
Therefore, the place for verification and reasoning
has no need for wind and pitch.
Is it not so?
Could it be that only the music master Kuang, with his extensive knowledge and erudition,
had the means to know the shape of victory and defeat,
wishing to solidify the hearts of the masses,
and thus relied on mysterious subtleties,
like Bo Changqian's prediction of Duke Jing's lifespan?
Furthermore, it is difficult to say:
that the mother of Yangshe heard her child cry
and determined it would lead to the ruin of her family.
I ask again, how did she know this?
Was it that her divine mind alone comprehended it,
and she spoke darkly but correctly?
Or had she heard a child cry before,
so loudly and horribly,
and now this crying sound
resembled the crying sound of the past?
Therefore, she knew it would lead to the ruin of her family?
If it were that her divine mind alone comprehended it,
and she spoke darkly but correctly,
it would not be something attainable through reason.
Although it is said to "listen to crying,"
there is no way to verify anything from the sound of a baby's cry.
If one considers a previously heard sound to be bad,
and therefore knows that the present cry must be bad,
this is to take the "A" sound as a standard,
to compare against the "B" baby's cry.
Now, the relationship of sound to tone
is like the relationship of appearance to the heart.
There are those whose appearances are similar but whose feelings are divergent,
and those whose appearances are different but whose hearts are equal.
How can we demonstrate this?
The sages had equal hearts and equal virtue,
yet their forms and appearances were different.
If hearts are the same but forms are different,
then how can we speak of observing form and knowing the heart?
Moreover, the mouth expelling air to produce sound,
how is it different from pipes and flutes receiving air and making noise?
The goodness or badness of a crying sound
does not depend on the baby's mouth being auspicious or inauspicious,
just as the clarity or turbidity of a zither or lute
does not depend on the skill or clumsiness of the player.
The heart can discern principles and speak eloquently,
but cannot ensure that the inner pipes are finely tuned,
just as a blind person can be skilled in their melodies and rhythms,
but cannot ensure that the instrument necessarily produces clear and harmonious sounds.
An instrument does not become good by relying on a skilled blind person,
and a pipe does not become tuned because of a kind heart.
Thus, the heart and sound
Clearly, they are two separate things.
If these two things are indeed separate,
then one who seeks the truth of emotions does not dwell on outward appearances,
and one who measures the heart does not rely on listening to sounds.
Is not one who seeks to understand the heart through sound
going too far externally?
Now, the mother from Jin did not seek counsel from experienced elders,
but solely trusts the sounds of yesterday
to confirm today's cries.
Is she not mistakenly following the curiosity seekers of the past,
and thus being praised by them?"
The Qin guest challenged, saying:
"I have heard that a defeated man does not feel shame in fleeing,
because it is a means of survival.
My heart is not yet weary,
and if words are difficult,
I will return to other arguments.
Now, a person of calm disposition,
upon hearing zheng, flute, and pipa,
becomes restless in form and soaring in spirit;
upon hearing the sounds of the qin and se,
becomes quiet in hearing and at ease in heart.
Within the same instrument,
the use of different melodies is often distinct,
and thus the emotions change accordingly.
Playing Qin melodies brings sighs of admiration and fervor,
playing Qi and Chu melodies brings singleness of feeling and focused thought,
To indulge in dalliance is to revel in uninhibitedness and seek satisfaction.
The heart changes with the sound,
and in this way, it is manifold.
If agitation and tranquility depend on sound,
then why limit its sadness and joy?
Yet it is said that the most harmonious sound
moves everything.
To entrust the Great Harmony to sound
and attribute all changes to human emotion,
is it not to know the one while not understanding the other?"
The host replied, saying:
"It is argued:
'The pipa, zheng, and flute
make people agitated and unrestrained.'
It is also said:
'The melodies vary,
and emotions change accordingly.'
This is indeed why they constantly move people.
The pipa, zheng, and flute
have rapid tempos and high pitches,
with numerous variations and frequent beats.
Using high sounds to control frequent beats
therefore makes
people agitated and their minds unrestrained,
just as bells and clappers alert the ear
and chimes and drums startle the heart.
Therefore, hearing the sound of drums and war drums
then one thinks of generals and ministers.
It is because sounds have large and small (volumes),
therefore they move people with intensity or tranquility.
The structure of the qin and se
is spacious and resonant, yet the tones are humble;
the variations are sparse, yet the sound is clear.
If one uses humble tones to govern sparse variations,
and does not listen with an empty and quiet mind,
then one will not fully appreciate the ultimate harmony,
therefore listening quietly brings a tranquil mind.
The uses of melodies differ,
just as the sounds of different instruments do.
The melodies of Qi and Chu are often layered,
therefore the emotion is singular;
their variations are subtle,
therefore the thought is focused.
The music of skilled performers
draws from the beauty of many sounds,
and combines the harmony of the five tones.
Its structure is rich and its application broad,
therefore the mind is occupied with many principles;
the five tones combine,
therefore one feels joyous and seeks satisfaction.
However, all take singularity/duality, high/low, good/bad as their structure,
while human emotion responds with agitation/stillness and concentration/dispersion.
It is like going sightseeing in a bustling market:
the eyes are overwhelmed and the emotions are unrestrained;
carefully observing the nuances of melodies,
Then thought is calmed and appearance is composed.
This is the essence of sound,
exhausted in its slowness and speed;
the response of emotion to sound
is also limited to agitation and stillness.
Now, musical compositions each employ unique methods,
and the variations of emotion
are like different exquisite flavors,
which the mouth immediately recognizes.
The myriad flavors are all different,
yet they largely converge on the concept of deliciousness;
though musical variations are numerous,
they also largely converge on the concept of harmony.
Deliciousness has sweetness,
harmony has pleasure;
however, following the emotion of the music,
it is exhausted within the realm of harmony;
the mouth responding to deliciousness
is cut off at the point of sweetness.
How could one obtain sorrow and joy from within them?
However, human emotions differ,
and what the teacher explains,
will elicit what is held within the heart.
If one were to say that peacefulness, sorrow, and joy are equally valid,
then there would be nothing to elicit first,
and ultimately one would obtain agitation and stillness.
If there is something elicited,
then there is a ruler within,
It is not for the sake of harmony.
Speaking in this way,
agitation and tranquility
are the effects of sound;
sorrow and joy
are the masters of emotion.
It is unacceptable to see that sound has responses of agitation and tranquility,
and therefore conclude that sorrow and joy are all caused by sound.

there is not even a day's worth of merit.
This is why a gentleman sighs.
As for Shen Xu's prolonged lament,
Yi and Qi's complete purity,
Zhan Ji's adherence to trustworthiness,
and Su Wu's upholding of integrity,
they can be said to be resolute.
Therefore, using a mind without ulterior motives to guard it securely,
and embodying it,
is like it is natural.
This is truly the height of upholding one's aspirations.
Regarding the superiors you live with,
you should simply respect them,
One should not be overly intimate with others;
one should not visit too frequently;
visits should be occasional.
When with a crowd of people,
one should not be the last to leave alone,
and one should not stay overnight.
The reason for this is that
superiors like to inquire about external affairs,
and sometimes initiate investigations,
then those who bear grudges will say that someone informed on them,
and one will have no way to exonerate oneself.
Act with magnanimity, speak sparingly,
be cautious and self-protective,
and the path of resentment and blame will be cleared.
One's personal conduct should be pure and aloof.
If there are troublesome requests,
or demands that people risk their lives,
or entrusted requests from others,
one should humbly decline with polite words;
if one has never been involved in such matters,
one should be candid about it.
If there are urgent grievances,
that one cannot bear in one's heart
one can outwardly refuse,
but secretly help them.
The reason for this is that
it keeps one far from the possibility of currying favor with superiors,
cuts off the excessive demands of ordinary people,
Even a minimal offering of dried meat as tuition deserves the praise of being without blemish;
this is another aspect of upholding one's will.
In all actions, first examine whether they are permissible.
If something is appropriate,
if it is appropriate to do something,
and people want to change it,
you should explain the reason why it is appropriate to change it.
If their words are truly excellent,
do not be ashamed to abandon your own view;
if their reasoning is insufficient,
and they further seek to sway you with emotion, then hold firm to what you believe.
Even if people keep talking,
you should firmly hold to what you uphold,
this is another aspect of upholding one's will.
There is no need to display the petty pride of a small tuition offering;
if you see someone in poverty
and there is a way to help them,
then do what is right.
If someone asks you for something,
first reflect on yourself;
if the harm and waste are great,
and the benefit of helping today is small,
then you should weigh the importance and refuse them.
Even if they continue to plead shamelessly,
you should still refuse them.
Generally, when people ask for something,
it is because they lack what you have,
therefore they come to ask you;
This is because you have given too much.
To not be like this
is to be frivolous and easily exhausted.
Unable to say it to your face,
I reluctantly convey a small part of my feelings.
This is not to be considered having high aspirations.
Now, speech
is a gentleman's pivot;
when the pivot moves and things respond,
then the forms of right and wrong become clear.
Therefore, one must be careful.
If something seems unclear to you,
but you originally intended to speak,
then you should fear the loss of clarity
and temporarily restrain yourself.
Afterwards, observe whether not speaking of this matter has
no other negative consequence;
if so, then speaking about it earlier might have had negative consequences.
If you can refrain from speaking,
you will perfectly attain what is acceptable.
Moreover, common people are slow to spread good news but quick to spread bad news;
they also like to discuss the faults and shortcomings of others.
This is the usual way of people's discussions.
What is said in gatherings
is seldom profound discussion.
Rather, it is often news of events and changes,
and small differences.
You should look upon such things with lofty indifference,
and not deem it worthwhile to respond.
Do not speak unless it is righteous,
carefully maintain tranquility, and respectfully follow the Way.
Is this not what is meant by having few regrets?
When people are in conflict and arguing,
not knowing where gain and loss lie,
be careful not to get involved.
Rather, observe it in silence,
and the right and wrong of their actions will naturally become visible.
Perhaps there are small rights that are not worth righting,
and small wrongs that are not worth wronging.
In the end, it may be better to remain silent and wait for the outcome.
Even if someone asks you about it,
you should still decline by saying you do not understand.
The same applies to recent debates.
If you are at a drinking party
and see people arguing,
and the situation seems likely to escalate,
you should simply leave without a word.
This is a sign that a fight is about to break out.
Watching from the sidelines will inevitably reveal who is right and who is wrong.
Being involved, you cannot avoid having opinions.
If you have opinions, you will inevitably side with one person.
The one who is in the wrong
will consider himself to be in the right,
and will think that those who say he is wrong are biased towards the other party.
Then feelings of resentment and animosity will arise.
Or you may even receive insulting words.
Just watching it happen,
greatly seeing the right and wrong,
and not being able to resolve the dispute,
is being benevolent but lacking in martial skill.
It is not justifiable in terms of righteousness.
Therefore, you should stay away from it.
However, in general, those who engage in lawsuits
are petty people.
Even if there is indeed right and wrong,
and they jointly engage in dissolute behavior,
even if you win, is it really worth praising?
If you cannot avoid it, it is better to become drunk.
If there is something you happen to want to conceal in your mind,
and they insist on knowing it,
if you firmly guard against it without ceasing,
or they attempt to coerce you with base emotions,
you must not fear these petty people
and be swayed by them.
Lead them to exhaust their words.
Now, if you are firm in your speech,
saying you do not know and do not recognize,
this is the mark of a man of ambition.
Unless they are old friends or neighbors,
or those of lower rank,
wanting to invite you,
you should decline with some other excuse
and not go.
To consider external glory as something to desire less,
Unless it is extremely urgent,
ultimately having no desires or wants
is the highest excellence.
There is no need for petty displays of humble respect,
but one should embody great humility and generosity.
There is no need for petty displays of integrity and shame,
but one should practice complete and great yielding.
If facing court, yield office;
facing righteousness, yield life,
like Kong Wenju requesting to die in place of his brother,
this is the integrity of a loyal minister and a heroic scholar.
Ordinary people naturally have public and private matters,
so be careful not to force others to know.
If they know that I know,
then they will harbor resentment towards me.
Now, knowing but not speaking,
is equivalent to not knowing at all.
If you see whispered private discussions,
then immediately leave,
so as not to make others resent you.
Or, if at times forced
to discuss something together,
and if their words are wicked and dangerous,
then you should correct them with a stern face and with righteousness.
Why?
Because the gentleman does not tolerate false and shallow words.
If something fails one day,
they will say, "So-and-so knew about my affairs in the past,"
Therefore, one should prepare deeply.
Generally, in private conversations,
there is nothing that is not discussed.
One should anticipate this and be mindful.
Why does one run away upon seeing it?
Why is that?
Perhaps one accidentally knows their private affairs.
If you agree with them, it is fine.
If you disagree, they will fear the matter being leaked
and will think of harming others to cover their tracks.
If someone you don't respect
comes to tease or ridicule,
mocking others' shortcomings,
just don't respond, don't engage,
and shift to not engaging.
And don't be overly haughty and aloof,
respond with silence.
The situation cannot last long,
and their actions will naturally stop.
If it is not someone you supervise,
and there is no other suitable reason for associating,
but they show intentions of bringing wine and food,
or gifts of dried meat as a token of respect,
this is common human interaction
and need not be refused.
Beyond this,
unless you are very close and harmonious,
gifts of silk,
Gifts of carriages and clothing
should be firmly declined.
Why?
Common people all value profit and belittle righteousness.
One who exhausts himself
certainly acts with a purpose, acting as a vendor,
selling favors and seeking recompense.
This is what vulgar people are pleased to do,
but what gentlemen greatly detest.
[Illegible characters] also muddle-headed,
do not push away or hold back,
but strongly urge people to drink.
If you do not drink yourself,
and someone comes to urge you,
you should always take the cup for them,
and do not scold or resist.
Stop when you see they are tipsy and flushed,
and be careful not to let them get so drunk
that they cannot control themselves.

Nineteen Poems Presented to My Elder Brother, the Scholar-Official Gong Mu, Upon His Joining the Army
A pair of phoenixes hid their shining brilliance,
Folding their wings at the foot of Mount Tai.
Raising their heads to rinse in the morning dew,
Drying in the sun, they stirred their fine plumage.
Long cries echoed playing among the clouds,
At times descending to rest in orchid pools.
They thought themselves free from worldly dust,
And believed they would remain so forever.
Why is the world so full of hardship?
The hunter comes, viewing me with suspicion.
Nets of cloud block the four quarters of the sky,
Tall nets are spread out unevenly.
Struggling vigorously is of no use,
My six wings have nowhere to spread.
Hiding my form, I submit to the long cord,
And am ultimately constrained by the times.
Alone and heroic, I turn and flee in solitude,
Grievingly lamenting, I am wounded by being separated from life.
Hesitating, I long for my companions,
Full of emotion, I stand upon the high mountain slope.
When the birds are gone, the good bow is stored away,
When plans are exhausted, one's body is certainly in danger.
Though good and bad fortune lie within oneself,
The paths of the world are full of peril.
How can I return to my original state,
Embracing jade, treasure the six wonders?
To freely roam in the Great Purity,
Hand in hand, forever following each other.
The mandarin ducks fly,
Their feathers rustling.
In the morning, they roam the high plains,
In the evening, they rest on the orchid isle.
Harmoniously chirping together,
They gaze back at their companions,
Looking down, looking up, full of emotion,
Leisurely and at ease.
The mandarin ducks fly together,
calling their companions and summoning their friends.
In the morning, they roam the high plains;
in the evening, they rest on the midstream islet.
With necks intertwined, they flutter their wings,
leisurely and at ease in the clear stream.
They chew on orchids and fragrant herbs,
bowing and raising their heads, leisurely and at ease.
Swimming in that long river,
I will rest on its bank;
Climbing that high hill,
I will cut down the chaste tree.
Alas, for my journeying,
I walk alone, solitary.
Looking up at the gentle southern breeze,
Tears fall like rain!
Swimming in that long river,
I will rest on its islet;
Climbing that high hill,
I will cut down the willow tree.
Alas, for my solitary journey,
I have nothing to look to, nothing to rely on.
Looking up at the gentle southern breeze,
I both sit and rise.
Gently blows the favoring wind,
Moving, that light dust;
Sparkling, the white ripples;
Turning, those swimming fish.
Such is my toil,
I cherish thoughts of a fair one.
Waking, I speak of eternal longing,
Truly devoted to my beloved.
Where is my beloved?
She has left me far away.
Abandoning this sweet fragrant iris,
She dons that bitter artemisia.
Though it is said to be secluded and deep,
How can there be no tumbles and falls?
Thinking of you, my lord,
May there be no distant harm.
Human life is short,
Heaven and earth are long lasting.
A hundred years' time,
Who would call that long-lived?
I think of ascending to immortality,
In order to achieve imperishability.
Holding the reins, I hesitate,
Looking up, I consider my friend.
Where has my friend gone?
Separated by these hills.
Who says the river is wide?
A single reed can be sailed.
Vainly I lament our eternal separation,
The road to the afterlife stretches long.
Gazing upwards, I cannot reach you,
Moving to and fro, I wander in confusion.
My fine horse is well-trained,
My beautiful garments gleam brightly.
In my left hand, I grasp the "Fanruo" bow,
In my right, I hold the "Wanggui" arrow.
Like wind it gallops, like lightning it flashes,
Treading on shadows, chasing after flight.
Fiercely traversing the Central Plains,
A glance around, and beauty is born.
Taking along my beloved companions,
Riding in my light carriage,
Southwards I cross the long hills,
Northwards I skim the clear streams.
Looking up, I startle the soaring wild geese,
Looking down, I draw forth the deep-dwelling fish.
I linger in hunting and pleasure,
Such joy is only temporary.
Ascending high, I gaze into the distance,
Looking down, I sigh and lament.
I resent my confinement in this secluded place,
The distant road stretches far away.
Though I have fine music,
With whom shall I sing a pure song?
Though I possess beautiful features,
who is there to bring forth their splendor?
I look up and inquire of the high clouds,
I look down and entrust myself to the gentle waves.
Riding the current, I flee far away,
embracing regret in the mountain recesses.
A light carriage swiftly advances,
resting in that long forest.
The spring trees are laden with glory,
spreading leaves and casting shade.
The whispering valley wind,
blows upon my plain zither.
The chirping yellow birds,
look to their companions and play with sounds.
Awakened by emotion, my thoughts race,
I think of the one I admire.
My heart is filled with sorrow,
I sigh and chant endlessly.
The vast, surging river,
encircles my nation;
the lush green forest,
flourishes and radiates light.
Fish and dragons ripple and play,
mountain birds fly in flocks.
I speak of setting out on a journey,
forgetting to return day and night.
I think of my good friends,
As if thirsty and hungry.
I wish to speak with them, but cannot obtain it;
Alas, how sorrowful is that!
I rest my feet in an orchid garden,
And feed my horses at Mount Hua.
I wander by the banks of the Pan River on a level plain,
And cast my line in the long river.
My eyes follow the returning wild geese,
My hands play the five-stringed lute.
Looking down and looking up, I find contentment,
And let my mind wander in the Great Mystery.
Admirable is that old fisherman,
Who, having caught the fish, forgets the trap.
The man of Ying is gone;
Who can fully express my feelings?
A quiet night is serene and pure,
A bright moon shines upon the window.
A gentle breeze stirs the sleeves,
And the curtain tassels are raised high.
Fine wine fills the cup,
But there is no one to share my joy with.
The zither and lute are at hand,
But who will play them with me?
I yearn for those who share my interests,
Whose fragrance is like orchids.
The beautiful one is no longer here;
how can I not sigh eternally!
Riding the wind, I travel high,
far ascending the sacred hill.
Entrusting myself to the good deeds of Song and Qiao,
hand in hand, we wander together.
In the morning, we depart from Mount Taihua,
in the evening, we rest in the divine land.
Playing the zither and chanting poetry,
I briefly forget my sorrows.
The zither and poetry are my own joy;
distant travels are truly precious.
Embracing the Tao, I go alone;
abandoning wisdom, I discard my body.
Silent and without burdens,
what do I seek from others?
I will long reside on the sacred mountain,
pleasing my will and nourishing my spirit.
The common people are difficult to enlighten;
they chase after things and never return.
The perfected person sees far,
returning to nature.
All things are one;
the four seas are our common home.
I share it with them;
what is there for me to begrudge?
Life is like a floating sojourn,
A brief glimpse, then suddenly the end.
Worldly affairs are chaotic and confused;
Discard them eight or nine tenths.
Though a swamp pheasant is hungry,
It does not desire the gardens and forests.
How can I bear to be burdened with service and governance,
Toil my body and embitter my heart?
I value my person, deeming fame as cheap;
Where do honor and disgrace lie?
I value gaining the freedom to fulfill my ambitions,
To let my heart roam without regret.
"A Poem of Secluded Resentment"
Alas, my meager blessings,
In youth, I encountered adversity.
Pitifully alone and ignorant,
I was still wrapped in swaddling clothes.
Mother and elder brothers nurtured me,
With kindness but without severity.
Relying on love, I indulged in recklessness,
Untutored and without a teacher.
When I reached the age of adulthood,
I relied on favor and indulged myself freely.
My heart aspired to the ancients,
Following whatever I valued.
I entrusted my affections to Laozi and Zhuangzi,
Deeming material things cheap and the self as valuable.
My ambition lies in maintaining simplicity,
nurturing the essential and preserving truth.
I say that I am not clever,
I love goodness, yet I am blind to people's true nature.
The failure of Ziyu,
has repeatedly increased my faults like dust accumulating.
Great men are generous and broad-minded,
they conceal filth and harbor shame.
The people's many deviations,
are due to the government not being conducted properly.
It is only this narrow mind of mine,
that makes judgements of good and bad so obvious.
Feeling remorse and reflecting on my faults,
it is as painful as a fresh wound.
Wanting to reduce my faults,
criticisms and slanders are rife.
My nature is not to harm things,
yet I frequently incur resentment and hatred.
In the past, I was ashamed compared to Liuxia Hui,
now I am ashamed compared to Sun Deng.
Inwardly, I betray my long-held aspirations,
outwardly, I am ashamed before my good friends.
I admire Yan Zizhang and Zheng Zichan,
for delighting in the Way and living in peaceful seclusion.
Without striving with the world,
their spirit and energy are serene.
Alas, I am not virtuous,
and am burdened with many anxieties.
It did not fall from the sky;
It was truly caused by my own obstinacy and carelessness.
The principles were neglected, troubles accumulated,
Finally leading to imprisonment.
Responding to vulgar interrogations,
I am bound by this dark obstacle.
I am truly ashamed to plead for justice,
Time does not favor me.
Although I speak of righteousness and integrity,
My spirit is disgraced, and my will is frustrated.
Cleansing my body in the Canglang River,
How can it truly compensate?
The wild geese cry mournfully,
Flapping their wings to travel north.
Moving in accordance with the season,
They find joy and forget sorrow.
Alas, I sigh in indignation,
But have no one to share my plight.
Events go against my wishes,
Encountering this prolonged stay.
Success and failure are determined by fate,
So what more should I seek?
The ancients had a saying:
"Of all good things, none is closer than reputation."
Following the times with respectful silence,
Faults and regrets will not arise.
Wan Shi was circumspect,
Bringing peace to his parents and preserving his honor.
Worldly affairs are chaotic,
only disturbing my feelings.
One must be warned when in ease and comfort,
then in the end, it will be advantageous and correct.
The glorious Ganoderma lucidum
blooms three times a year.
Why am I alone,
with aspirations unfulfilled?
Punishing myself for the difficulties, I think of returning,
my heart feels inner guilt.
I hope to encourage myself in the future,
to be neither fragrant nor foul.
Gathering ferns on the mountain slopes,
letting my hair down in the rocky peaks.
Forever whistling and chanting,
nurturing my nature and nourishing my longevity.

A Poem on Wandering as an Immortal
From afar, I gaze upon the pine on the mountain,
In the deep valley, it flourishes, verdant and lush.
How exceedingly lofty is its self-encounter,
Standing alone, unparalleled and unique.
I long to wander beneath it,
But the path is completely impassable.
Wang Qiao abandoned me and departed,
Riding the clouds, driving six dragons.
Drifting and playing in the Xuanpu Garden,

Making friends with the family of Ban Tong.

Ten poems in six-character lines
Only the ancient Yao and Shun,

Noble, simple, kind, and obedient,

Calming them with stillness, he becomes correct himself.

This naturally leads to diligence, hardship, and unrest.
Endlessly accumulating riches invites misfortune.
A hall filled with gold and jade cannot be guarded forever;
The ancients were content with simple and coarse things.
They solely befriended virtue and morality;
Therefore, they could extend their lives and achieve immortality.

and Wang Qiao descended, parting the clouds.
The phoenix danced on the courtyard steps,
The wandering maiden floats and gathers here.
Feeling Heaven and Earth to bring about harmony,
How much more so for the myriad crawling creatures?
Praising the excellence and luxuriance of this instrument,
I sing this poem to console myself.
Forever using and enjoying it without weariness,
Truly, it is valued by both the ancients and the moderns.
Epilogue:
Deep and serene is the virtue of the zither,
Immeasurable it is!
Its form is pure, its heart is distant,
So lofty, it is hard to reach!
Fine material and beautiful hands,
Meet in this present age!
A rich and harmonious resonance,
Surpasses all other arts!
Few know music,
Who can cherish it?
Able to fully master the refined zither,
Only the perfect man!
Letter Breaking Off Relations with Shan Juyuan (Shan Tao)
Kang Bai (Respectful greeting):
In the past, you praised me in Yingchuan,
I always said you understood my words.
Yet I have always been surprised by this opinion,
As I am not yet that familiar with you,
How did you manage to obtain it?
The year before last, when I returned from Hedong,
Xian Zong's son, A Du, said that you had considered recommending me as your replacement.
Although the matter did not go through,
I knew that you were unaware of it.
You are broadly knowledgeable,
accepting of much and critical of little.
I am of straightforward and narrow temperament,
intolerant of many things.
It was merely by chance that I became acquainted with you.
Recently, I heard of your promotion,
and I was genuinely not pleased.
I fear that you, like the butcher who desires to monopolize the meat cutting,
might bring in the corpse-invoker to assist yourself.
Personally wielding the sacrificial knife,
smearing it with greasy stench.
Therefore, I have fully presented to you what is acceptable and what is not.
In the past, when I read books,
I learned of the existence of unyielding individuals;
some said they did not exist,
but now I believe they truly do.
There are things that one's nature cannot tolerate,
and they truly cannot be forced.
Now, it is empty talk to say that a wise person can tolerate anything,
outwardly conforming to customs,
while inwardly not losing one's integrity;
going with the flow of the world,
and not giving rise to regret or remorse.
Laozi and Zhuang Zhou,
they are my teachers,
yet they willingly lived in humble positions.
Liu Xia Hui and Dongfang Shuo,
they were men of understanding,
content in their lowly status.
How could I dare to criticize them?
Furthermore, Zhong Ni (Confucius) embraced universal love
and was not ashamed to hold the whip (a low-ranking job).
Zi Wen had no desire for the position of prime minister,
yet he thrice rose to the position of Ling Yin (chief minister of Chu).
This is precisely the intention of a virtuous man to benefit all things.
What is called "success is the ability to do good to all without wavering,
adversity is self-contentment without sorrow."
Viewed in this way,
thus Yao and Shun ruled the world,
Xu You dwelled in caves,
Zifang assisted the Han dynasty,
Jie Yu went about singing;
their principles are the same.
Looking up to these several gentlemen,
it can be said that they were able to fulfill their aspirations.
Therefore, the gentleman's hundred actions,
though different paths, lead to the same goal.
Acting according to their nature,
each adheres to what brings him peace.
Thus, there is the saying: "One can be in the court without leaving it,
or enter the mountains and forests without turning back."
He admired the demeanor of Yanling Gao Zizang,
and Changqing emulated the integrity of Sima Xiangru.
Their aspirations and integrity were something
that could not be taken away.
Every time I read the biographies of Shang Ziping and Tai Xiaowei,
I deeply admired them,
and I imagined what kind of people they were.
From a young age, I was orphaned and exposed,
indulged by my mother and older brothers,
and did not delve into classical studies.
My nature is also unrefined and lazy,
my muscles are weak and my flesh is slack.
My head and face often go fifteen days to a month without being washed.
Unless I feel unbearable itching,
I am unable to bathe.
I often hold back my urine and don't get up,
only getting up when my bladder has slightly shifted.
Moreover, I have been indulging myself for a long time,
my feelings are arrogant and unrestrained,
simplicity and propriety are at odds,
laziness and arrogance reinforce each other.
Yet I am treated with leniency by my peers,
and they do not criticize my faults.
Furthermore, reading Zhuangzi and Laozi
only increased my wildness,
thus causing my desire for glory and advancement to decline daily,
and my inclination for practicality to become more steadfast.
This is because if birds and deer are rarely seen and tamed from youth,
then they obey the established rules and regulations;
but when they grow up and are restrained,
they will wildly look around and break their reins,
rushing into boiling water and flames.
Even if adorned with golden bits,
and fed with delicious food,
they still long for the long forest,
and their heart is set on the abundant grass.
Ruan Sizong never discussed the faults of others,
I always try to emulate him,
but have not been able to reach his level.
His true nature surpassed others,
and he did no harm to anything,
only his drinking was excessive.
Consequently, he was bound by those who valued propriety and law,
who hated him like an enemy,
and he was fortunate to have been protected by the General.
I am not as virtuous as Sizong,
and I have shortcomings of negligence and laxity.
Furthermore, I do not understand human nature,
I am ignorant of what is expedient,
I do not have the caution of Wan Shi,
but I have the misfortune of being too exhaustive.
Having been involved in affairs for a long time,
my faults and flaws grow daily.
Even if I want to have no worries,
how can that be possible?
Moreover, human relationships have propriety,
The court has laws;
considering myself, even to the point of familiarity,
there are seven things that I absolutely cannot endure,
and two that are exceedingly unbearable.
I am pleased to wake up late,
yet the gatekeeper calls out incessantly;
this is the first thing I cannot endure.
Holding a zither and reciting poetry,
hunting and fishing in the wilderness,
yet the clerks and soldiers guard me,
and I cannot move freely;
this is the second thing I cannot endure.
Sitting upright for a long time,
my limbs become numb and I cannot move,
and my nature is also prone to lice,
scratching myself without end;
yet I must be wrapped in official robes,
bowing and saluting superiors;
this is the third thing I cannot endure.
I am naturally not skilled at writing,
and I also do not enjoy writing;
yet human affairs are many,
piling up on my desk and filling my seat.
If I do not respond,
then I violate teachings and injure righteousness;
if I try to force myself,
then I cannot last long.
This is the fourth thing I cannot endure.
I do not enjoy attending funerals,
yet people consider this important.
I have been resented by those who have not forgiven me,
to the point that I may be slandered.
Although I am startled and blame myself,
my nature cannot be changed.
Wanting to humble himself and conform to customs,
his insincerity appears contrived and unnatural,
and he ultimately cannot escape blame.
Lacking praise in this way,
this is the fifth thing he cannot endure.
He dislikes vulgar people,
yet must work with them.
Sometimes guests fill the seats,
their noisy chatter grating on his ears.
The noisy dust and foul smells,
with endless performances and tricks,
are constantly before his eyes.
This is the sixth thing he cannot endure.
His heart is impatient,
yet his official duties are pressing and overwhelming.
Bureaucratic tasks entangle his mind,
worldly affairs burden his thoughts.
This is the seventh thing he cannot endure.
Furthermore, he often criticizes Tang and Wu,
and disparages the Duke of Zhou and Confucius.
He does not stop at just this in the world,
and will inevitably be rejected by the established doctrines;
This is the first thing that is utterly impossible to change.
I have an unyielding disposition and hate evil,
and I recklessly speak my mind directly,
erupting at every occasion;
this is the second thing that is utterly impossible to change.
With this narrow-minded, cautious temperament
governing these nine flaws,
if there is no external trouble,
there will certainly be internal illness.
How could I possibly live among people for long?
Moreover, I heard the dying words of a Taoist priest,
that taking Atractylodes and Polygonatum root
can grant people longevity.
I deeply believe this.
Wandering through mountains and marshes,
observing fish and birds,
my heart greatly rejoices in this.
But once I become an official,
this pursuit will be abandoned.
How can I abandon what I enjoy
and follow what I fear?
In the relationship between people who truly understand each other,
it is valued to recognize the other's natural disposition,
and then to assist them based on that.
Yu did not force Bo Chengzi,
because he wished to preserve his integrity.
Confucius did not lend an umbrella to Zixia,
because he sought to protect his shortcomings.
Zhuge Kongming did not force Yuanzhi to enter Shu,
and Hua Ziyu did not compel Youan to become a high-ranking minister.
This can be called being able to see things through to the end,
and being a true understanding friend.
You see that straight timber cannot necessarily be used to make wheels,
and crooked timber cannot necessarily be used to make rafters;
this is probably because you don't want to bend their natural talents
and allow them to find their proper place.
Therefore, the four classes of people have their own occupations,
and each finds pleasure in fulfilling their ambitions.
Only those who are enlightened can understand this,
and this is within your capacity to understand.
You cannot just because you like the Zhangfu hat,
force the Yue people to wear a civil official's coronet.
It's like someone who loves the smell of rotten things,
feeding baby mandarin ducks with dead rats.
I have recently been learning the art of nourishing life,
turning away from outward glory and splendor,
rejecting rich flavors,
and letting my mind wander in solitude,
valuing inaction.
Even without the nine troubles,
I would still not care for what you like.
Moreover, I have a heart ailment,
which has recently become increasingly severe.
I have privately tested myself
and cannot endure what I dislike;
I have already made a careful prediction.
If it is said that the road has reached its end,
then so be it.
You have no reason to wrong me,
causing me to roll into a ditch.
I have recently lost the joy of my mother and brother,
and my heart is constantly filled with sorrow.
My daughter is thirteen years old,
and my son is eight years old,
not yet adults;
moreover, they are often ill.
Looking at them, I am full of longing and sorrow;
how can I even speak of it?
Now I only wish to stay in my humble alley,
teaching and raising my children and grandchildren,
occasionally conversing with relatives and old friends about our separation,
recounting our lives.
A cup of muddy wine,
a tune played on the zither,
and my ambition is fulfilled.
If you continue to pester me relentlessly,
it is merely because you want to find talented people for official positions,
to benefit the affairs of the time.
You know of old that I am unaccomplished and crude,
inept at handling affairs,
and I believe I am even less capable than those who are wise and capable today.
If you think that common people all delight in glory and wealth,
and that you alone can detach yourself from them and take pleasure in this,
this is the most readily available thing one could say.
Then cause their talent and breadth
to be all-encompassing,
and yet be able to remain unconcerned with personal gain;
only then are they truly valuable.
As for me, I am often ill,
burdened and wishing to leave affairs to preserve myself completely,
in order to protect my remaining years;
this is truly what I lack;
how can I be like a eunuch praising chastity?
If one rushes to ascend the royal path together,
hoping to achieve something together,
and at times provide pleasant benefits,
then suddenly pressure them,
it will surely trigger their madness.
If not for deep resentment,
it would not come to this.
There is a rustic who finds pleasure in warming his back by the fire and enjoying the taste of water celery,
and wishes to offer it to the most honored one.
Although he has good intentions,
he is already estranged.
I hope you will not be like him.
My meaning is thus.
This is both to explain myself to you,
and to serve as a farewell.
Ji Kang writes.
A Letter of Severance to Lü Changti, one piece.
Kang writes:
Formerly, when comparing our ages,
we frequently met and became close.
Your sincerity
resulted in a great friendship.
I still considered you a close friend.
Although we took different paths in life,
our affection for each other did not diminish.
Later, I came to know a little about A-du,
and his aspirations became clear.
I was always pleased that your family had such a brother,
but last year A-du told me
that he was truly angered by your intention to take action [against him].
I deeply restrained him,
relying on my own estimation that you were not someone to be pushed,
so he listened to me.
Sometimes I instructed you,
because he obeyed me,
to be obedient to your relative [A-du],
truly cherishing your family's reputation,
wanting to ensure that neither of you would suffer harm.
Furthermore, you promised me that you would never attack A-du,
swearing an oath on the relationship between father and son.
I was moved by the seriousness of your words
and comforted A-du,
and A-du was then relieved.
He no longer suspected you,
but secretly harbored doubts,
and secretly reported an attack on A-du,
First, you accused Du.
This was because of Du,
and I believed you and had no further comment.
What was the meaning of you harboring such a malicious heart?
Du's tolerance of you
was truly due to my words.
Now that Du is guilty,
I take responsibility for it.
My responsibility for Du
stems from your betrayal of me.
I am sadly at a loss,
what more can I say!
If this is the case,
I have no intention of associating with you again.
The gentlemen of old never spoke ugly words when ending a friendship;
from now on, we are separated!
I am filled with resentment at our parting.
