One poem from the Bu Yi Collection
There was a Mr. Hongda:
He had a broad and magnanimous character,
quiet, solitary, and aloof.
He was upright but not rigid,
honest but not harsh.
He surpassed the world and walked alone,
Carrying jade, he wears coarse cloth.
In friendships, he does not seek unprincipled alliances;
In seeking office, he does not aim for advancement.
He always considers loyalty, sincerity, honesty, and respect
to be the true path and acts accordingly;
he can live among the nine Yi tribes,
travel among the eight Man tribes,
float on the vast sea,
and set foot on the source of the Yellow River.
Armed soldiers are not to be feared,
fierce beasts are no cause for concern.
Therefore, scheming intentions do not exist,
and he is serenely pure and simple;
at ease and unconstrained,
forgetting likes and dislikes.
He considers the Way of Heaven as his sole guide,
and does not concern himself with the trivial details of worldly things.
However, since the Great Way has become hidden,
cleverness and ingenuity have flourished;
worldly customs are stubbornly adhered to,
and human emotions are multifaceted.
Wherever profit lies,
people flock to it like birds chasing a phoenix.
Wealth becomes accumulated corruption,
nobility becomes a gathering of resentment,
activity brings many burdens,
while tranquility brings few troubles.
Therefore, I think of the hermits in the hills,
I find joy in fishing with a rod by the River Le.
Thereupon, my thoughts drift afar, and I engage in prolonged contemplation,
feeling transcendent and losing myself.
Now that the craftsman of Ying is gone,
who can appraise my true nature?
I cannot meet the Sage,
but I hope to hear of him through numerology.
Therefore, I went to the dwelling of the Grand Historian Zhenfu,
and asked him,
"I have some doubts,
and I wish you to divine them for me."
Zhenfu then sat upright, held the yarrow stalks,
wiped the table, and displayed the tortoise shell, saying,
"What do you wish me to foretell?"
The gentleman said,
"Would I rather rise up in righteous anger and speak frankly in the imperial court,
delivering honest words to the emperor’s court
and not yield to kings and dukes?
Or would I rather be base and weak, compliant and yielding,
following orders and leaning dependently,
being obedient in appearance only?
Would I rather be kind and magnanimous, spreading benevolence
and bestowing favors without seeking gratitude?
Or would I rather strive for worldly gain,
seeking only to accommodate and ingratiate myself?
Would I rather live in seclusion and practice righteousness,
promoting utmost sincerity, or cultivate outward adornment and deceit,
nurturing an empty reputation?
Would you rather denounce and banish the wicked and flattering,
upholding righteousness without wavering,
discerning good from evil?
Or would you rather be haughty and scoffing,
relying on cunning and employing schemes,
acting as a strategist?
Would you rather befriend Wang Qiao and Chisongzi?
Or would you rather recommend Yi Yin
and befriend Shangfu?
Would you rather conceal your scales and hide your brilliance,
like a dragon in the depths?
Or would you rather spread your wings and raise your voice,
like a swan in the clouds?
Would you rather outwardly transform your appearance,
inwardly concealing your feelings,
bending your body to follow the times,
sinking into obscurity without fame;
though in the human world,
in reality dwelling in darkness?
Or would you rather strive to be pure,
sharpen your thoughts to be refined,
act differently from the world,
but have your heart alongside common customs;
everywhere you are, you must be heard, constantly bustling about?
Would you rather be solitary and free,
without anything to boast about or value;
considering others and yourself as one,
not striving, not yielding;
letting your mind wander in pure simplicity,
suddenly sitting in oblivion;
pursuing Xi and Nong but failing to reach them,
walking halfway and feeling despondent?
Or would you rather be generous and consider it noble,
and be moved by emotion and consider it virtuous?
To reach up to the emperor,
and look down upon generals and ministers;
to hold one's countenance with dignity,
and maintain a lofty, unyielding bearing;
always appearing as though you have lost your position,
harboring resentment and discontent?
Would you rather accumulate a thousand billion in wealth,
strike bells and eat from tripods;
recline among fragrant pillows,
and delight in the beauty of concubines?
Will you instead endure hardship and exert your strength,
cutting away thorns and brambles;
dwell in the mountains and drink from the valleys,
leaning against rocks to rest?
Would you rather be like Bo Fen and Zhong Kan,
who, at sixteen, became married couples;
and排擯共鯀 (expelled and rejected Gonggong),
causing him to lose his position?
Will you be like the hermit of Jishan,
or the recluse of the Ying River;
lightly regarding Tang and Yu,
and laughing at the Great Yu?
Would you rather be like Taibo, whose virtue was hidden,
concealing and yielding without boasting?
Or would you rather be like Ji Zha, whose integrity and righteousness were manifest,
admiring Zizang and striving to be like him?
Would you rather be like Lao Dan, whose purity and subtlety were profound,
guarding the mysterious and embracing the One?
Or would you rather be like Zhuang Zhou, whose perspective equated all things, embracing change,
penetrating and unrestrained?
Would you rather be like Yi Wu, not tolerating restraint,
and ultimately establishing hegemonic achievements?
Or would you rather be like Lu Lian, who took the world lightly and indulged his ambitions,
discoursing loftily with composure?
Would you rather be like the Master of the Southern Market, whose divine courage was inwardly firm,
with a will as deep as mountains and abysses?
Or would you rather be like Mao Gong and Lin Sheng, whose valorous advance was like that of dragons and tigers,
striving to be valiant warriors?
Who gains and who loses in these paths?
What is inauspicious and what is auspicious?
Times change and customs shift,
people favor wealth and admire fame;
Zang Wen did not cede his position to Liu Ji,
and Gongsun did not attribute merit to Dong Sheng;
Jia Yi, once favored by an enlightened ruler,
caused Jiang and Guan to change color and raise their voices in protest.
How much more so now, with a thousand dragons racing together,
ten thousand steeds galloping in unison;
a chaotic competition,
fleeting like shooting stars.
How dare I not seek counsel from experienced elders!"
Grand Historian Zhenfu said:
"I have heard that the most virtuous person does not need physiognomy,
and the enlightened person does not need divination.
A person like you, sir,
possesses brilliance within,
and embraces simplicity and unadorned nature.
Your conscience is clear within,
and you do not betray common customs outwardly.
You do not associate for personal gain,
and you do not seek a salary in service.
You are knowledgeable about the past and present,
cleansing your emotions and dissipating desires.
If one is like this,
one can roam the Lüliang Mountains,
and bathe in the Valley of Tang;
one is about to observe the great Peng bird in the Southern Sea,
so why worry about the complexities of the human world!"
On Nourishing Life, a Treatise
There are those who say that immortality can be learned,
and that not dying can be achieved through effort.
Others say that the highest lifespan is one hundred and twenty years,
which is the same in ancient and modern times;
beyond this,
everything is nothing but monstrous falsehoods.
These both miss the mark.
Allow me to attempt a rough discussion.
Now, although Immortals cannot be seen with the eyes,
yet what is recorded in the written records,
and what is transmitted in previous histories,
when compared and discussed,
their existence is certainly assured.
It seems that they especially receive extraordinary qi,
endowed to them naturally,
and cannot be attained through accumulated learning.
As for guiding and nurturing (the body) with proper principles,
so as to fulfill one's nature and life,
to obtain a thousand-plus years in the upper end,
and several hundred years in the lower end,
that is something that can be achieved.
But the world is not skilled in this,
therefore no one can attain it.
How can I say this?
Now, taking medicine to induce sweat,
sometimes one does not obtain it;
but once a feeling of shame gathers,
it dissipates and flows away in abundance.
Having not eaten all morning,
one clamorously thinks of food,
but Zengzi, holding sorrow, did not hunger for seven days.
Sitting until midnight,
one droopingly thinks of sleep;
inwardly harboring deep worries,
one does not close their eyes until dawn.
Vigorously brushing the temples and hair,
Rich wine brings color to the face,
but this is only achieved with restraint.
The anger of a strong man,
is a startling and distinct sight,
hair standing on end, bursting through the crown.
From this we can say that,
the spirit is to the physical body,
as the ruler is to the state.
If the spirit is agitated within,
then the body decays outwardly;
it is like the ruler being foolish above,
and the state descending into chaos below.
Suppose that in the time of Tang
someone farming had only the benefit of one watering,
though it will ultimately still wither and rot,
that one watering will at least delay its drying out.
Therefore, the benefit of that one watering,
should not be dismissed as false.
But the world commonly says that one bout of anger is not enough to harm one’s nature,
one instance of sorrow is not enough to injure one’s body;
they take it lightly and indulge in it.
This is like not recognizing the benefit of a single watering,
and yet expecting good grain from drought-stricken seedlings.
Therefore, the wise man knows that the body relies on the spirit to stand,
and the spirit requires the body to exist.
He understands that the principles of life are easily lost,
and knows that harm arises from a single transgression.
Therefore, he cultivates his nature to preserve his spirit,
To settle the mind is to secure the whole body.
Love and hate do not dwell in the emotions,
worry and joy do not remain in the thoughts.
Being indifferent and without sensation,
the body's energy is harmonious and peaceful.
Furthermore, regulate breathing and exhalation,
and nourish the body with diet;
causing the physical form and spirit to be intimate,
both the exterior and interior are benefited.
Now, concerning farmers who cultivate fields,
one mu (unit of area) yielding ten hu (unit of volume),
is called a good field.
This is the common designation throughout the land.
But without knowing how to intensively cultivate,
one could yield over a hundred hu.
Cultivating a field is the same,
but as for the methods of planting and nurturing being different,
the results of the harvest are greatly different.
To say that merchants have no hope of tenfold profits,
and farmers have no expectation of a hundred hu harvest,
this is to be confined by the constant and unchanging.
Furthermore, beans make one feel heavy,
elm makes one feel sleepy,
mimosa relieves anger,
daylilies forget worries.
This is known by both the foolish and the wise.
Pungent and spicy things harm the eyes,
pigs and fish do not thrive,
These are things commonly known in the world.
Lice live on the head and are black,
musk deer eat cypress and are fragrant,
necks are in dangerous places and develop goiters,
teeth reside in Jin (a place known for its water quality) and are yellow.
Extrapolating from this,
the qi of whatever is consumed steams the nature and dyes the body,
invariably corresponding.
How could it be that only steams can make heavy,
and not make light;
harm can make dark,
and not make bright;
fumigation can make yellow,
and not make hard;
fragrance can make fragrant,
and not make lasting?
Therefore, Shen Nong said:
"Superior medicine nourishes life,
and medium medicine nourishes nature,"
truly understanding the principles of nature and life,
and thus assisting and nourishing them to reach their full potential.
Yet people of the world do not observe this,
only seeing the five grains,
and indulging in sounds and sights;
eyes are misled by dark and bright colors,
ears strive for lewd and alluring sounds;
rich flavors sear their internal organs,
sweet wine boils their intestines and stomach,
Fragrance and perfume rot its bone marrow.
Joy and anger violate its proper Qi,
thought and anxiety wear away its spirit,
sorrow and pleasure bring disaster to its balanced purity.
Indeed, with such a tiny frame,
the attackers come from more than one direction;
with such an easily depleted body,
it suffers enemies both external and internal;
the body is not wood or stone,
how can it last long?
Those who indulge themselves excessively,
are intemperate in eating and drinking,
thereby generating a hundred diseases.
They are tireless in pursuing beauty and lust,
thereby leading to exhaustion and depletion.
They are afflicted by wind and cold,
and wounded by a hundred poisons.
They die prematurely amidst many difficulties,
and the world all knows to laugh and lament,
calling it a failure to properly maintain life.
As for those who err in the way they conduct themselves,
they perish from small beginnings,
accumulating small things into loss,
accumulating loss into decline,
from decline they attain gray hair,
from gray hair they attain old age,
from old age they attain the end,
bewildered as if without cause.
Those of middling intelligence and below,
call it natural.
Even if they awaken somewhat and all sigh,
regretting the beginning of what they encountered,
they do not know to be cautious of the many dangers before they are manifest.
This is like Lord Huan embracing a disease that will kill him,
and being angry at Bian Que's foresight;
taking the day he feels pain
as the beginning of his illness.
Harm is formed in the minute,
but they try to remedy it when it is obvious,
hence there is governance without merit.
They gallop within the realm of ordinary people,
hence they have an ordinary lifespan.
Looking up and observing down,
everything is like this.
They prove themselves with the majority,
and comfort themselves with conformity,
saying that the principles of Heaven and Earth
are exhausted in this alone.
Even if they hear of matters of nurturing life,
they judge it based on what they have seen,
saying it is not so.
The next level of people are doubtful, though slightly less so,
but almost do not know the reason why.
The next level of people rely on their own strength to take medicine,
for half a year or a year,
toiling without verification;
Ambition flags and wanes,
and midway the endeavor is abandoned again.
Some add drainage ditches,
and discharge it through the tail's end,
yet desire to sit and await manifest reward.
Some suppress emotions and restrain desires,
cutting off and discarding aspirations of glory,
yet pleasures remain constantly before their eyes and ears,
and what they hope for lies decades in the future.
They also fear losing both,
inwardly harboring doubt,
the heart warring within,
things tempting from without,
mutual borrowing undermining each other,
and thus they fail again.
For the ultimate thing is subtle and profound,
able to be understood by reason,
difficult to be discerned by the eyes.
It is like the *yuzhang* tree,
only after seven years of growth can it be detected.
Now, with an impetuous and competitive heart,
one treads the path of seeking stillness;
intention is quick, but the matter is slow,
hope is near, but the response is far;
therefore, none can see it through to the end.

Not ceasing the activity of the mind
is the fifth difficulty.
If these five things are certainly present,
even if one's heart hopes for longevity,
the mouth recites the most profound words,
one chews on the essence of excellence,
and breathes in the sun’s rays,
one cannot but reverse one's principles
and shorten one's years.
If these five things are absent from one's breast,
then trust and obedience increase daily,
and mysterious virtue becomes daily complete.
Without praying for happiness, one will have good fortune;
without seeking longevity, one will naturally extend one's life.
This is the effect of the great principle of nurturing life.
However, there are those whose conduct surpasses that of Zeng and Min,
embracing benevolence and righteousness,
acting according to moderation and harmony,
without any great burdens,
and who then consider human principles to be complete,
and boast of themselves for this reason.
But without controlling joy and anger
and harmonizing the spirit and qi,
yet desiring to repel old age and prolong life,
I have not heard of it.
Some elevate their aspirations, longing for antiquity,
and do not glory in fame and position.
Therefore, they regard themselves as superior to those who rush about busily.
Some employ their wisdom to govern the world,
without encountering disaster,
and thus consider themselves noble.
This, in terms of using one's person, is simply like being of the same age as the elders in one's village.
To speak of preserving life,
is largely absent.
Some renounce the world and are not part of the crowd,
their will and spirit harmonious and pure.
Yet, not ceasing to eat grains and chewing on herbs
is of no benefit to a short life.
If, however, one has stored up jade provisions,
and can control the six qi (vital energies) simultaneously,
and is able to contain light and look inward,
concentrate the spirit and return to the uncarved block,
lodging the mind on the cliffs of profound darkness,
and holding qi on the shores of the immeasurable,
then one can repel old age
and prolong life.
All these methods, when combined for use,
cannot do without one another.
They are like the axle, wheel, and linchpin
none of which can be lacking in a chariot.
However, if people are biased,
each suffers from their particular affliction.
